question_text: Which type of graph would you use to show the temperature outside each day for one week?

solution: The best type of graph to show the temperature outside each day for one week is a line graph. It shows a value that changes over time. Example:
The other types of graphs are not as good.
A stem-and-leaf plot shows the numbers in a large data set arranged by place value. Example:
A pictograph compares two or more values that are multiples of a number. Example:
A double bar graph compares two sets of data. Example:
solution_image_tag: This image shows a line graph titled 'Spelling words practised' with the horizontal axis labeled 'Day' and the vertical axis labeled 'Number of spelling words'. Data points are plotted for each day of the week from Thursday to Wednesday, connected by a line that shows changes in the number of words practiced over time.

This image shows a stem-and-leaf plot titled 'Restaurant ratings'. The 'Stem' column shows digits representing the tens place (1 to 4), and the 'Leaf' column shows digits representing the ones place of the ratings.

This image shows a pictograph titled 'Can recycling drive'. It displays three rows labeled 'Whitney', 'Jayla', and 'Tristan', with soda can icons representing the number of cans each person collected. A key at the bottom indicates that each can icon equals 1 can.

This image shows a double bar graph titled 'Buildings'. The horizontal axis is labeled 'Materials' and includes categories such as 'Stucco', 'Stone', 'Brick', and 'Concrete'. The vertical axis shows the 'Number of buildings'. Each category has two bars: one green bar for 'Banks' and one blue bar for 'Restaurants', allowing comparison of material use across the two types of buildings.
